contentrichtext.text: [[File:PolarisMissileIWMLondon.jpg|thumb|right|British UGM-27 Polaris missile on display at Imperial War Museum London]] The '''Polaris Sales Agreement''' was an agreement between the [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]] which began the [[UK Polaris programme]]. The agreement formally arranged for the [[UGM-27 Polaris|Polaris]] missile system to be provided to the UK to maintain its independent nuclear deterrent.<ref name=McGeoch-1975>{{Cite document|url=http://www.rnsubmus.co.uk/coldwar/McG.pdf|format=PDF|title=The British Polaris Project|author=Vice-Admiral Sir [[Ian McGeoch]]|publisher=University of Edinburgh (MPhil)|year=1975|accessdate=2008-07-30|postscript=<!--None-->}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The arrangement had been set up in principle as a result of the [[Nassau Agreement]]. The agreement was amended in 1982 to provide the [[Trident (missile)|Trident missile]] system to the UK. The United Kingdom had been planning to buy the air-launched [[GAM-87 Skybolt|Skybolt]] missile but the USA decided to cancel the Skybolt program in 1962 as they no longer needed the missile. The British bought the Polaris submarine-launched ballistic missile instead. The Nassau Agreement was signed on December 18, 1962 resulting in the signing of the Polaris Sales Agreement on April 6, 1963. The United States would supply the United Kingdom with Polaris missiles, launch tubes, and the [[fire-control system|fire control system]]. The UK would make the warheads and submarines. In return, the U.S. was given certain assurances by the United Kingdom regarding the use of the missile, however the U.S. does not have any veto on the use of British nuclear weapons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Freedom of Information Request About the UK Nuclear Deterrent|publisher=Directorate of Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear Policy|url=http://www.mod.uk/linked_files/publications/foi/rr/nuclear190705.pdf|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20051229080220/http://www.mod.uk/linked_files/publications/foi/rr/nuclear190705.pdf|deadurl=yes|archivedate=2005-12-25|accessdate=2011-12-11}}</ref> The British Polaris submarines were the [[Resolution class submarine|''Resolution'']]-class [[ballistic missile]] [[submarine]]s, the first of which entered service in 1968. The Polaris system underwent a British-designed life extension programme called ''[[Chevaline]]'' that reduced the number of warheads and added defensive measures. ==Trident== {{main|UK Trident programme}} [[File:Trident II missile cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Trident II D5 Missile launch]] The Polaris Sales Agreement was used as the model for the UK's purchase of the Trident weapon system to replace Polaris in British service.<ref name=NAO-1987>{{cite book|title=Ministry of Defence and Property Services Agency: Control and Management of the Trident Programme|publisher=[[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]]|date=29 June 1987|pages=Part 4|isbn=0-10-202788-9|nopp=true}}</ref> The arrangements were almost identical to that for Polaris, the United Kingdom procured the Trident system from America and fitted them to their own submarines, the ''[[Vanguard class submarine|Vanguard]]''-class. [[HMS Vanguard (S28)|HMS ''Vanguard'']] entered operational service in December 1994. British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] had written to [[Jimmy Carter|President Carter]] on July 10, 1980 to request that he approve supply of Trident I missiles.<ref>White Paper Cmnd 7979 July 1980 - The British Strategic Nuclear Force</ref> However in 1982 Thatcher wrote to [[Ronald Reagan|President Reagan]] to request the United Kingdom be allowed to procure the Trident II (Trident D5) system, the procurement of which had been accelerated by the US Navy. This was agreed in March 1982.<ref>White Paper Cmnd 8517 March 1982</ref><ref>[http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1982/31182b.htm Reagan letter to Thatcher]</ref> Under the Polaris Sales Agreement, the United Kingdom paid a 5% levy on the cost of equipment supplied in recognition of US research and development costs already incurred. The R&D contribution to Trident comprised payments amounting to $116M with no on-going R&D levy.
